case_vignette: A 33-year-old Black man presents to a dermatology clinic with a 5-month history of asymptomatic lesions on his arms and trunk. He is otherwise healthy with no personal or family history of skin disease. He has no history of fever, cough, shortness of breath, or joint pain. The patient has not tried any treatments for these lesions. On examination, there are several smooth, well-demarcated hypopigmented plaques on his upper arms and left flank. He has no similar lesions elsewhere on his body.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have some painless colorless spots on my arms and side for about 5 months.
Have you noticed any changes in size, shape, or quantity of these spots over time?
No, they have stayed pretty much the same since I noticed them.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 33-year-old man.
Do the spots itch, scale, or bleed?
No, they don't itch, flake, or bleed.
Have you had any recent illnesses, like infections, or experienced any other symptoms?
No, I haven't been sick nor have I had any other symptoms.
Do you have a history of skin conditions, either personally or in your family?
No, I don't have any personal or family history of skin problems.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you used new skin products recently?
No, I haven't tried any treatments or new skin products.
Is there any loss of sensation or numbness in or around the spots?
No, I don't feel any numbness or loss of sensation in those areas.
Have you been exposed to the sun or UV light extensively, or do you use sunscreen regularly?
I haven't mentioned anything about sun exposure or sunscreen use.
Are the spots located only on areas exposed to the sun or are they also present on areas typically covered by clothing?
The spots are on my upper arms and left side, so they're not just in sun-exposed areas.
Have the spots lightened the skin in these areas, and do the borders of the spots appear well-defined?
Yes, the spots have lightened the skin and have clear, well-defined edges.
Final Diagnosis: Idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis.

trial_3.vignette_frq: The final diagnosis could be idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis or postinflammatory hypopigmentation, but a definitive diagnosis would require further investigation including, for example, a Wood's lamp examination, fungal cultures, or a skin biopsy to rule out other conditions such as tinea versicolor or vitiligo.
